metadata.title: Convert Bits to Terabytes
metadata.description: Convert bits (b) to terabytes (TB) using the SI decimal convention, with examples and notes on binary alternatives.

introduction: This converter translates a value in bits into terabytes (TB) using the SI decimal definition where 1 TB = 10^12 bytes. It is designed for large-scale capacity planning, data-transfer estimation, and reporting.
methodology: Base identity: 1 byte = 8 bits. Decimal prefixes: 1 TB = 1,000,000,000,000 bytes.
Conversion path: bits → bytes (÷8) → terabytes (÷10^12). Combined: TB = bits ÷ (8 × 10^12).
Binary option: for tebibytes (TiB), use 1 TiB = 1,099,511,627,776 bytes (2^40). The bit-to-byte step remains ÷8; only the divisor changes.
how_is_calculated: Round outputs for display as needed; keep full precision internally.
examples: 8,796,093,022,208 bits → 1 TiB (binary reference), which equals about 1.0995 TB under decimal prefixes.

faqs.question: Which convention does this converter follow by default?
faqs.answer: The default is decimal SI: 1 TB = 10^12 bytes. Use the TiB divisor for binary contexts.

faqs.question: Why does an OS show a different value for the same drive size?
faqs.answer: Many operating systems use binary units (TiB) while vendors use decimal (TB). The byte count is the same; the displayed number changes because of the divisor (10^12 vs 2^40).

faqs.question: How should I round for reports?
faqs.answer: For summaries, 2–3 significant digits are common. For technical or contractual documents, keep more precision and state the unit and convention used.

summary: TB = bits ÷ (8 × 10^12) for decimal terabytes; use the TiB divisor if you need binary units.
